document.title: Positive definite functions, completely monotone functions, the Bernstein-Widder theorem, and Schoenberg’s theorem

para.p:
For a complex Hilbert space
H
let
⁢ L
( H )
be the bounded linear operators
→ H H
. It is a fact that
∈ A
⁢ L
( H )
is self-adjoint if and only if
∈
⟨
⁢ A h
, h ⟩
R
for all
∈ h H
. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 John B. Conway, A Course in Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 33, Proposition 2.12. For a bounded self-adjoint operator
A
it is a fact that 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 John B. Conway, A Course in Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 34, Proposition 2.13.

Math.text: norm@(A) = (supremum _ (norm@(h) = 1))@(absolute-value@(list@(A * h, h)))

para.p:
∈ A
⁢ L
( H )
is called positive if it is self-adjoint and

Math.text: formulae@(list@(A * h, h) >= 0, h element-of H)

para.p:
because we have taken
H
to be a complex Hilbert space, for
A
to be positive it suffices that the inequality is satisfied.

For
∈
A , B
⁢ L
(
C n
)
, we define their Hadamard product
∈
* A B
⁢ L
( H )
by

Math.text: A * B * e _ i = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(list@(A * e _ i, e _ j) * list@(B * e _ i, e _ j) * e _ j)

para.p: So,

Math.text: list@(A * B * e _ i, e _ j) = list@(A * e _ i, e _ j) * list@(B * e _ i, e _ j)

para.p:
The Schur product theorem states that if
∈
A , B
⁢ L
(
C n
)
are positive then their Hadamard product
* A B
is positive. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Ward Cheney and Will Light, A Course in Approximation Theory, p. 81, chapter 12.

Let
X

: f

X

by

where

absent = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ i * overline@(u _ j) * f * (x _ i - x _ j)))
absent = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ i * overline@(u _ j) * f * (x _ i - x _ j)))

para.p:
We call
f
positive definite if for all
∈
x 1
, … ,
x n
X
,
F
f ;
x 1
, … ,
x n
is a positive operator, i.e. for
∈ u
C n
,

Math.text: list@(F _ (list@(f, x _ 1, ldots, x _ n)) * u, u) >= 0

para.p:
We call
f
strictly positive definite for all distinct
∈
x 1
, … ,
x n
X
and nonzero
∈ u
C n
,

Math.text: list@(F _ (list@(f, x _ 1, ldots, x _ n)) * u, u) > 0

para.p:
A function
: f
→
[ 0 , ∞ )
R
is called completely monotone if

Math.text: f element-of C * closed-open-interval@(0, infinity)
f element-of C ^ infinity * open-interval@(0, infinity)

para.p:
Because a completely monotone function is continuous,
⁢ f
( x )
tends to
⁢ f
( 0 )
as
↓ x 0
. Because a completely monotone function is nonincreasing and convex,
⁢ f
( x )
has a limit, which we call
⁢ f
( ∞ )
, as
↑ x ∞
.

The Bernstein-Widder theorem states that a function
f
satisfying
=
⁢ f
( 0 )
1
is completely monotone if and only if it is the Laplace transform of a Borel probability measure on
[ 0 , ∞ )
. 4 footnote 4 4 footnote 4 Peter D. Lax, Functional Analysis, p. 138, chapter 14, Theorem 3; http://djalil.chafai.net/blog/2013/03/23/the-bernstein-theorem-on-completely-monotone-functions/

A function
: f
→
[ 0 , ∞ )
R
satisfies
=
⁢ f
( 0 )
1
and is completely monotone if and only if there is a Borel probability measure
μ
on
[ 0 , ∞ )
such that

Math.text: formulae@(f * x = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- x * t) * differential-d@(mu) * t), x element-of closed-open-interval@(0, infinity))

If
f
is the Laplace transform of some probability measure
μ
on
B

absent less= (2 / t) * ((integral _ (t / 2)) ^ t)@((- 1) ^ k * f ^ k * u * differential-d@(u))

para.p:
Doing induction, for any
≥ k 1

Math.text: (- 1) ^ k * f ^ k * t less= ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ (k - 1))@(((2 ^ j / t) cdot f ^ prime) * (t / 2 ^ (k - 1)))
absent less= ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ (k - 1))@(((2 ^ j / t) cdot f ^ prime) * (t / 2 ^ (k - 1)))

Because
→

para.p: and

para.p:
For

Math.text: f * x - f * infinity = - ((integral _ x) ^ infinity)@(f ^ prime * t * differential-d@(t))
f * x - f * infinity
absent = - ((integral _ x) ^ infinity)@(f ^ prime * t * differential-d@(t))
absent = (- evaluated-at@((t - x) * f ^ prime * t, x, infinity)) + ((integral _ x) ^ infinity)@(f ^ prime2 * t * (t - x) * differential-d@(t))
absent = (- evaluated-at@((t - x) * f ^ prime * t, x, infinity)) + ((integral _ x) ^ infinity)@(f ^ prime2 * t * (t - x) * differential-d@(t))

absent = - ((integral _ x) ^ infinity)@(f ^ prime3 * t * ((t - x) ^ 2 / 2) * differential-d@(t))

absent = (- 1) ^ k * ((integral _ x) ^ infinity)@(f ^ k * t * ((t - x) ^ (k - 1) / (k - 1)factorial) * differential-d@(t))

para.p:
Hence for
≥ x 0
and
≥ n 0

para.p: Define

Math.text: phi _ n * y = (1 - y / n) ^ n * 1 _ (closed-interval@(0, n)) * y

para.p:
For
≥ n 1
, by change of variables,

f * x - f * infinity
absent = ((- 1) ^ (n + 1) / nfactorial) * ((integral _ (x / n)) ^ infinity)@(f ^ (n + 1) * n * u * (n * u - x) ^ n * n * differential-d@(u))

absent = ((- 1) ^ (n + 1) / (n - 1)factorial) * ((integral _ (x / n)) ^ infinity)@(f ^ (n + 1) * n * u * (n * u) ^ n * (1 - x / (n * u)) ^ n * differential-d@(u))
absent = ((- 1) ^ (n + 1) / (n - 1)factorial) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((n * u) ^ n * phi _ n * (x / u) * f ^ (n + 1) * n * u * differential-d@(u))

absent = ((- 1) ^ (n + 1) / (n - 1)factorial) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((n / t) ^ n * phi _ n * x * t * f ^ (n + 1) * (n / t) * t ^ (- 2) * differential-d@(t))

para.p:
For
≥ t 0
, define

The total variation of
σ n

s n

s n

Math.text: norm@(sigma _ n) = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(absolute-value@((s _ n) ^ prime * t) * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((s _ n) ^ prime * t * differential-d@(t)) = s _ n * infinity - s _ n * 0 = s _ n * infinity

The following lemma asserts that a certain function is nonzero
λ d
-almost everywhere, where
λ d
is Lebesgue measure on
R d
. 10 footnote 10 10 footnote 10 Ward Cheney and Will Light, A Course in Approximation Theory, p. 91, chapter 13, Lemma 6.

Let
x 1
, … ,
x n
be distinct points in
R d

∈ u
C n
not be the zero vector, and define

para.p:
For
λ d
-almost all
∈ y
R d

The following theorem gives conditions under which the Fourier transform of a Borel measure on
R d
is strictly positive definite. 11 footnote 11 11 footnote 11 Ward Cheney and Will Light, A Course in Approximation Theory, p. 92, chapter 13, Theorem 3.

If
μ
is a finite Borel measure on
R d
and
>

λ d

0

^ μ
→
R d
C

For distinct

R d

Math.text: ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * hat@(mu) * (x _ j - x _ k))) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * (integral _ (R ^ d))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * (x _ j - x _ k)) cdot y) * differential-d@(mu) * y)))

absent = (integral _ (R ^ d))@((absolute-value@(g * y)) ^ 2 * differential-d@(mu) * y)

It is apparent that this is nonnegative. If it is equal to
0
then because

Let

An identity that is worth memorizing is that for

Math.text: (integral _ R)@(e ^ (- pi * x ^ 2) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * y) * differential-d@(x)) = e ^ (- pi * y ^ 2)

Let
x 1
, … ,
x n
be distinct points in
X
. There is an
n
-dimensional linear subspace
V
of
X
that contains
x 1
, … ,
x n
. By the Gram-Schmidt process,
V
has an orthonormal basis
{
v 1
, … ,
v n
}
. Define
: T
→ V
R n
by
=
⁢ T
v j
e j
, where
{
e 1
, … ,

is the standard basis for
R n
, which is an orthogonal transformation, and define

Math.text: formulae@(f * u = e ^ (- alpha * (absolute-value@(u)) ^ 2), u element-of R ^ d)

para.p:
For
∈ u
C n
,
≠ u 0
,

Math.text: ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * e ^ (- alpha * (norm@(x _ j - x _ k)) ^ 2))) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * exponential@(- alpha * (absolute-value@(T * (x _ j - x _ k))) ^ 2)))
((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * e ^ (- alpha * (norm@(x _ j - x _ k)) ^ 2)))
absent = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * exponential@(- alpha * (absolute-value@(T * (x _ j - x _ k))) ^ 2)))
absent = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * f * (T * x _ j - T * x _ k)))
absent = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * f * (T * x _ j - T * x _ k)))

para.p:
Now, let
μ
be the Borel measure on
R d
whose density with respect to
λ d
is

Math.text: y maps-to (pi / alpha) ^ (d / 2) * exponential@(- (pi ^ 2 / alpha) * (absolute-value@(y)) ^ 2)

para.p:
Because
μ
is absolutely continuous with respect to
λ d
,
>
⁢
λ d
(
⁢ supp μ
)
0
, so Theorem states that the Fourier transform
:
^ μ
→
R d
C
is strictly positive definite. Applying Lemma , the Fourier transform of
μ
is

Math.text: hat@(mu) * u = (integral _ (R ^ d))@((pi / alpha) ^ (d / 2) * exponential@(- (pi ^ 2 / alpha) * (absolute-value@(y)) ^ 2) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * list@(y, u)) * differential-d@(y)) = e ^ (- alpha * (absolute-value@(u)) ^ 2) = f * u

para.p:
so
f
is strictly positive definite. Because
T
is an orthogonal transformation it is in particular one-to-one, so
⁢ T
x 1
, … ,
⁢ T
x n
are distinct points in
R d
. Thus the fact that
f
is strictly positive definite means that

Math.text: ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * e ^ (- alpha * (norm@(x _ j - x _ k)) ^ 2))) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(u _ j * overline@(u _ k) * f * (T * x _ j - T * x _ k))) > 0

para.p:
which establishes that
↦ x
e
-
⁢ α
∥ x ∥
2
is strictly positive definite. ∎

The following is Schoenberg’s theorem. 14 footnote 14 14 footnote 14 Ward Cheney and Will Light, A Course in Approximation Theory, p. 101, chapter 15, Theorem 1; René L. Schilling, Renming Song, and Zoran Vondraček, Bernstein Functions: Theory and Applications, p. 142, Theorem 12.14; William F. Donoghue Jr., Distributions and Fourier Transforms, p. 205, §41.

Let
( X ,
⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩
)
be a real inner product space. If
: f
→
[ 0 , ∞ )
R
is completely monotone,
=
⁢ f
( 0 )
1
, and
f
is not constant, then

Math.text: formulae@(x maps-to f * (norm@(x)) ^ 2, X to closed-open-interval@(0, infinity))

para.p: is radial and strictly positive definite.

Because
f
is completely monotone, the Bernstein-Widder theorem (Theorem ) tells us that there is a Borel probability measure
μ
on
[ 0 , ∞ )
such that

Math.text: formulae@(f * t = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- s * t) * differential-d@(mu) * s), t element-of closed-open-interval@(0, infinity))

para.p:
that is,
f
is the Laplace transform of
μ
. Now, the Laplace transform of
δ 0
is
↦ t 1
, and because
f
is not constant, the Laplace transform of
μ
is not equal to the Laplace transform of
δ 0
, which implies that
≠ μ
δ 0
. 15 footnote 15 15 footnote 15 Bert Fristedt and Lawrence Gray, A Modern Approach to Probability Theory, p. 218, §13.5, Theorem 6. Therefore
>
⁢ μ
(
( 0 , ∞ )
)
0
.
